Sorry I didn't catch the issue,
if CONF.compute_feature_enabled.block_migration_for_live_migration is set to False, that means the environment doesn't support block migration(e.g.,ceph), so, block_migration will set to False, what's wrong with this logic?
yeah this block is run for LiveMigrationTest which has microversion capped to 2.24 so skipping the block migration tests if block_migration_for_live_migration=False is right thing.

Yes that's correct but the problem for-ex In non-ceph env when we don't set the parameter in tempest.conf this would add block_migration= false at micro_version 2.24 and assume to be running the migration as shared storage live migration and thus it failed. So the user should set/unset this value as per the deployment and if it's not set then we shouldn't be running block migration at all.

However just FYI, this works fine on LiveAutoBlockMigrationV225Test with min_microversion =2.25 but we observe this only in 2.24 microversion

Yes! Will do.

It will, though one thing to note is that *during this transaction* if some bit of code looked at router.load_balancer, that entry would still show up if we don't explicitly delete it in the transaction. It is only at transaction commit time on the server itself that it will be automatically cleaned up.

Since for an update, we do a delete() and a create() in the same transaction, for the purposes of that transaction there will be two LB entries in router.load_balancer until we get the update from the DB when the transaction is committed. It doesn't look like anything would fail, though (but I did have to look pretty carefully to determine that).

tl;dr May not matter, but in general it is good practice to go ahead and delete the things that will be cleaned up automatically.

I did some poking around and consulted with my OVN gurus about this. Here is what I learned from Mark Michelson:

"<mmichelson> OVN allows load balancers to be set on logical switches or logical routers, actually. AFAIK, the load balancer works the same way on a logical switch as it does a logical router. That is, it's L3 load balancing. Typically in any sort of tests I run, I run load balancers on gateway routers. But I suppose that running a load balancer on a logical switch is used in cases where "internal" traffic needs to be load balanced. So E/W traffic that won't hit a GW router can get load balanced if necessary."

Since port forwarding is used for floating ip -- north/south -- and there will always be a router associated with it, I beleive that adding it to a LogicalSwitch is no aplicable. Sounds reasonable?

I don't understand this method.

1) The object updated is the LB, right? Why?
2) Instead of this, you should group the LB and the revisions and commit one single txn per LB register.

Right, this is for the ovn load balancer entries.
Here is the rub: The reviosion number for the load balancer entries follow the revision number of the floating ip, not the neutron port forwarding.

Also, there can only be 1 protocol per ovn lb entry. So 1 floating ip can map to 1 or 2 ovn load balancer entries: tcp and udp, which are unique baed on their name.

Please look at the doc in this gerrit for an example [1].

So, this function updates the 2 ovn lb entries that may exist for a given fip_id. I will add some comments here.

IIUC the network info will be "omitted" rather than "incorrect" if it is None. Am I parsing that right?
Note to self: on the surface, it looks like this being None (or formerly []) will cause a problem with cleanup. However...
From >= Train, we are saying this will be True...

And here we re-assign the unplug nw info with something from the migrate_data. That's why there's not an issue with cleanup >= Train.

And then for < Train, we'll have to use the other error message about cleanup being impacted. And we recognize that the impacted cleanup is no worse than the previous behavior of bailing out and not cleaning up at all.

So our goal is to get to post_live_migration on the source so we get the database updated to reflect the state of the instance better.

For < Train, where we will have unplug_nw_info = None, looking at the code in self.driver.post_live_migration_at_source, the only thing it does it unplug vifs, but I now see why you originally initialized network_info = [], the network_info needs to be iterable here for the unplug to be a no-op (linking the current stable/stein code here though it hasn't changed):

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/77225c9e83b38517696a3da206afcd609393b12c/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L884

otherwise we will raise and not proceed to the rest of post_live_migration on the destination.

So we *do* need network_info = [] on L8337 (with a code comment please, explaining why it needs to be []) and it would be nice if we cover that in a test somewhere... Ideally we'd want a func test that simulates this network_info fetch failure and asserts the expected instance.host afterward. Do we not have the ability to do that in a func test?

In a way it would be weird, yes, but my thinking was that if we have a code path on master, we could have test coverage for that path on master. What's the alternative? Adding stable-only test coverage for backports?

Hm, yeah I see now that unplug_vifs is just a pass in the fake driver, so that's not helpful. Maybe some sort of unit test then? Maybe a unit test that calls _post_live_migration and has get_instance_nw_info raise ConnectionError, then asserts that the network_info kwarg passed to _notify_about_instance_usage is []?

My overall thought on this is it seems more bad to not have any test coverage for something that would have not worked at all to fix the bug [in the < Train backports]. But I do see your point.

What do you think? Are you thinking to leave this change as-is and then when we get to the Stein/Queens backports, we change network_info = [] and then add a test for that, stable-only?

I note that the notifications code also expects network_info to be None if it's not to be used:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/97b0d251f7a5cc90d5a99a70499e57b1ae816b14/nova/notifications/base.py#L453

so on master, I agree that network_info = None is the best initial value.
fwiw, I see not reason to add the test when we get back to stable/queens

It'd be weird to have a functional test for something that can't happen on master, no? Also, we would have to do it with the real libvirt driver and fakelibvirt, and I'm not sure how well those support VIFs (live migration mostly works, it's how I did the NUMA live migration functional tests).

> we cover that in a test somewhere... Ideally we'd want a func test
 > that simulates this network_info fetch failure and asserts the
 > expected instance.host afterward. Do we not have the ability to do
 > that in a func test?

Note: I realize the func test would only apply to < Train though, so it wouldn't make real-life sense on the master change. But I don't think we could or should have a stable-only func test, it would be better IMHO to have the func test on this change if not 'vifs' in migrate data and then remove it at the same time the 'if migrate_data and 'vifs' in migrate_data:' condition is removed.

@stephen
 > fwiw, I see not reason to add the test when we get back to
 > stable/queens

You mean you're OK with a stable-only test?

@melwitt
 > so on master, I agree that network_info = None is the best initial

So is there consensus to do it with None on master, without any addition tests for code paths that can't get hit, and then move to [] in the backports, and add the test there?

I still have a comment from PS4 on this:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/729763/4/nova/compute/manager.py@8343

AFAICT the network info in the notification will be completely omitted if we pass network_info=None, so it seems like this should say something else like "omitted" for the >= Train changes right? And then for < Train it should says "incorrect".
Yep, sorry, was hard to untangle discussion and "-1 comments". Done now.

Assuming you're planning on backporting this can you capture some of the discussion in the change about this and just note that >= Train this omits network_info from the notification but before that it's just incorrect?
I'd rather not "pollute" master with talk of backports, but I'll definitely make a note of this in whatever release first hits the issue when I backport.
style nit: any chance you could drop this down to the next line? These severely indented hanging indents make my eyes bleed
Done
hmm I wonder if we want to assert that network_info is omitted in the func test?

Yeah, it was definitely mentioned before - calling Neutron over HTTP just for some (old school unversioned!!) notifications is pretty dumb, but I think fixing that should be part of a larger refactor. This isn't the first time we've had to do try/except to make sure we saved the instance correctly in case a REST call failed, it's a sign that we probably need to rejigger a bunch of stuff to be safer/smarter.

> hmm I wonder if we want to assert that network_info is omitted in

So initially I said "yeah ok", but then I started actually doing it, and it's just too much work methinks. We only do it in a handful of places, and it's basically proxying stuff from neutron, right? I wonder if this is this a hangover from nova-network days and, if so, whether we could think about dropping it now?

nit: non-zero doesn't necessarily mean correct

this whole line/pipeline feels icky/fragile

can you not use --format json | jq ...

and do something robust?

The problem with using jq here is that the json schema has changed in different ceph versions, so an additional query has to be made to determine the ceph version and then version-specific jq queries have to exist. This hassle can be avoided by using --format json-pretty and using grep to parse the output though. No head nor tail required and a single query works for every ceph version. If done correctly this can also be very robust.

/uc/index.html -> /tc/index.html
/uc/reference/running-a-uc-election.html -> /tc/index.html

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
can you elaborate on this please? Don't understand why it would return multiple entries, if you've a single entry for undercloud.ctlplane in hosts database. I assume the issue is somewhere else?

I've not seen this issue with redeploys.

Just try it yourself:
[root@undercloud ~]# echo '1.2.3.4 pippo.localdomain pippo.ctlplane' >> /etc/hosts
[root@undercloud ~]# getent hosts pippo.ctlplane
# Normal
1.2.3.4         pippo.localdomain pippo.ctlplane
# Now add another identical line
[root@undercloud ~]# echo '1.2.3.4 pippo.localdomain pippo.ctlplane' >> /etc/hosts
# Now getent hosts will add 'pippo.ctlplane' twice.
[root@undercloud ~]# getent hosts pippo.ctlplane
1.2.3.4         pippo.localdomain pippo.ctlplane pippo.ctlplane
1.2.3.4         pippo.localdomain pippo.ctlplane pippo.ctlplane

Now who adds those double entries you will ask. Well that is infrared, which I am trying to fix here:
https://review.gerrithub.io/c/redhat-openstack/infrared/+/497887

Even if we fix infrared, we should nonetheless make this more robust (in fact at least one customer hit this, and they were certainly not using infrared). I.e. there is nothing preventing a user or a setup to have twice the same entry on the undercloud, it's not super clean but it's not wrong, so we should be more robust in the face of that.
Actually, that's a great question. Why would more than a single IP address entry for a single FQDN to appear in /etc/hosts (aside of devops tooling bugs or manual intervention cases)?..

sushy/resources/updateservice/updateserv.message: The bug in the original code was that the above line passed a method name, instead of calling the method.  Missing () after the method name.
In addition to incorrectly passing the method name on the line above, this code was getting the path for SoftwareInventory when it should have been getting the path for FirmwareInventory.
Do we need explicit handling for empty path as we used to have in the method?

I don't believe so. I tested both of these methods against a Dell server with recent firmware.  It had a FirmwareInventory resource that contained data, but it did not have a SoftwareInventory resource.  In the SoftwareInventory case the code returns a SoftwareInventoryCollection that returns an empty list when get_members() is called:
https://github.com/openstack/sushy/blob/master/sushy/resources/base.py#L609
So I don't believe we need special handling for empty path.  This is a behavior change (returning basically empty list vs raising an ex), but the methods never worked anyway, so I don't think that matters either, and returning the empty list appears to be what it should do since that's what the infrastructure does.

I checked the current implementation in glance templates, and found there we have a task which ensure that shared directory, /var/lib/glance, has expected selinux context.
 https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/9ada168cb36974bd4313cedb659ad775a78d9525/deployment/glance/glance-api-container-puppet.yaml#L697-L701

I think keeping this is better even if nfs is used, not to change setype actually, but to ensure that this data share has expected selinux context. However I noticed that current order doesn't detect wrong selinux type as I said, so will update the patch to address that point.

openstack/utils.py.message:
Why not using `endswith`?

Also if I correctly understand this code you expect that an exception will be raised if fromisoformat meet the format iso8601, then this code could be simplified by using something:

```
date_str = date_str if not date_str.endswith("Z") else date_str[:-1]
return datetime.datetime.fromisoformat(date_str)
```

It will allow us to drop few statements and conditions and reduce to technical debt and dicrease related execution time.

Else rather than waiting for `Exception` I think we should catch `ValueError` to ensure to manage only this use case and lets side effects bubble up to catch them in logs later, here they will be hidden by a too low exception level.

Hum I agree that tweaking the  TZ could have some unforeseen side effects.

Ok for `endswith` thanks for your response.

because it is the same and simple python test shows [-1] works 5 times faster then .endswith

glance/common/scripts/image_import/main..message: This is obviously too frequent for real situations, but apparently we don't know what the size of the image will be here, even though it should be in staging. If we did, I would propose we set this to 5% of the image size. If we have to choose something static, I'd guess 1GiB, although even on a 10G link that will be fairly frequent, and be called a thousand times for a 1TiB image...

Should we increase this min_interval to some bigger value say 3 mins or 5 mins?

For bigger size of images (say 2 hours of operation) it will log this message for around 120 times. I am saying this because earlier we faced lots of issues due to large amount of logs (subunit parser error).

Changing this to less often increases the interval between the heartbeats, not just the logging. We could make the status logging less frequent independent of this. Note that the heartbeat function also does some data, so maybe we want this less frequent for that reason too, I'm not sure.

But yeah, whatever you think on the interval. I think it probably needs to be at least 4x as often as the lock-busting timeout to make sure we've had plenty of chances to update the task before the API is willing to bust it.
Agree, If possible we should definitely make the status logging less frequent.
